Andrea Goethals wrote:
> Hello,
> 
> I'm trying to understand the HostScope scope better so that I can make very 
> focused crawls. I have a crawl going that was started from 40 seeds using 
> the HostScope. I left the defaults of max-link-hops set to 25, 
> max-trans-hops set to 5 and max-path-depth set to 20. I configured it to 
> log any URIs that it considers out of scope. I can see in the 
> heritrix_out.log file that there are thousands of URIs that it is not 
> crawling because they are outOfScope. But in the crawl job report I can see 
> that is still crawling many hosts and retrieving files successfully from 
> hosts that are not the same as the hosts in the seed list. Is this normal 
> for the HostScope? Ideally I would like to be able to only retrieve files 
> from the hosts in the seed list or maybe go one link 'out' past the host.
> 
> BTW I'm using heritrix 1.6.

By default, Heritrix will include URIs that appear necessary to fully render
other URIs in the main scope -- such as embedded images, scripts, frames,
and resources referred to inside Javascript code.

This is probably what you are seeing. A way to tell for sure is to look
closely at the lines in crawl.log about the off-host URIs that were
included. After the URI itself will be a string of capital letters, such
as "LLE" or "LXXP". Each letter in this 'hops-path' indicates the type of
one 'hop' that led to this URL from a seed:

  L regular link (eg <A HREF="">)
  E 'embed' (eg <IMG SRC=""> or <FRAME SRC="">)
  R redirect/refresh
  P prerequisite (robots or DNS)
  X speculative -- best guess reference (URI-like strings found in Javascript)

A string of E/R/P/X hops, shorter than max-trans-hops, at the end of the
hops-path will cause otherwise out-of-scope URIs (such as off-host URIs) to
be included.

You can tighten the HostScope to never go off-host by setting 'max-trans-hops'
to 0.

Other notes:

- HostScope and its sibling scopes DomainScope and PathScope are rather
   inefficient in their testing of URIs (performing a linear probe of
   all allowed URI patterns). This doesn't matter much in small crawls
   (up to a few hundred seeds/allowed hosts) but can be a noticeable
   factor in larger (many thousand seeds/hosts) crawls.
- HostScope and its siblings also limit your ability to mix domain
   (http://*.example.com), host (http://example.com/*) and path
   (http://example.com/topic/*) scopes in a single crawl.
- SurtPrefixScope adds a little complexity but both improves the
   efficiency and mixing-flexibility of scope definition -- it can do
   everything HostScope/DomainScope/PathScope can do, and then some,
   more efficiently.
- For even finer-grained control, and sometimes greater efficiency,
   a DecidingScope with a customizable sequence of DecideRules can be
   used, though understanding/designing such scopes is harder.

Hope this helps,

- Gordon @ IA
